subjectDescription: Discover a full suite of online business courses that will allow you to make better business decisions and succeed in today's competitive business world. Our courses provide a rich learning experience that will allow you to develop critical business skills in areas such as business... Read more...
title: Fundamentals of Business Money Management
headline: Learn to grow and stabilize your business by executing practical money management strategies in this free online course.
description: Money is the lifeblood of any business and is key to its short and long-term success. Unfortunately, most companies fail because of poor money management. In this course, we will explore some common mistakes to avoid to make sure your business stays on top of its finances. We will also contrast profit, revenue, business expenses and cash flow. Finally, you will view how monitoring these factors can lead to the overall health of your business.
courseDescription:
Owning a small business can be rewarding but it can also be risky. Many businesses fail because they simply run out of money. While selling and making a profit, it is easy to think your business is doing well. However, without proper business budgeting and tracking expenses diligently, you may not easily discover that your business is suffering losses. This situation will make it difficult for you to stay on top of the overall health of your business and steer it toward greater success in the coming years. From the moment you begin this course, we address this issue.

Organizing your expenses into categories based on taxes and deductibles will help you have better control over your money. In addition, this will also aid you when filing your taxes. This course will provide information about managing your business's cash flow while recommending accounting software that makes the process seamless. You will also learn how to use other applications that help you generate a profit/loss statement and other essential documents to keep your business records up to date. Nevertheless, you will first see how to do this independently without these applications.

In the final section, you will learn about a common mistake that many small/medium business owners make: operating the same bank account for their expenses and business. On many occasions, this has caused severe problems for their companies. Besides being unable to ascertain how much money the firm is making or losing, they are forced to make higher tax payments based on the cash flow in the account. You will review practical suggestions on what to do to address this issue. Small and medium-sized business owners, as well as aspiring entrepreneurs, will benefit the most from taking this course. Enroll now and watch your business flourish!

Start Course Now
certificateDetail:
All Alison courses are free to enrol study and complete. To successfully complete this course and become an Alison Graduate, you need to achieve 80% or higher in each course assessment. Once you have completed this course, you have the option to acquire an official Diploma, which is a great way to share your achievement with the world.

Your Alison is:
  • Ideal for sharing with potential employers
  • Include it in your CV, professional social media profiles and job applications.
  • An indication of your commitment to continuously learn, upskill & achieve high results.
  • An incentive for you to continue empowering yourself through lifelong learning.
Alison offers 3 types of Diplomas for completed Diploma courses:
  • Digital : a downloadable in PDF format immediately available to you when you complete your purchase.
  • : a physical version of your officially branded and security-marked , posted to you with FREE shipping.
  • Framed : a physical version of your officially branded and security marked in a stylish frame, posted to you with FREE shipping.

All are available to purchase through the Alison Shop. For more information on purchasing Alison , please visit our FAQs. If you decide not to purchase your Alison , you can still demonstrate your achievement by sharing your Learner Record or Learner Achievement Verification, both of which are accessible from your Dashboard. For more details on our pricing, please visit our Pricing Page
slides:
• Learning Outcomes

  • On completion of this module, you will be able to:
    • Recognize the common mistakes in business money management and address them.
    • Explain the dangers of using the same bank account for both personal and business expenses.
    • Distinguish between profit, revenue, cash flow, and expenses, and identify how they impact your business.
    • Compute records of sales and expenses and evaluate how to be tax safe.
    • Categorize expenses in order to ascertain how money is being spent.
    • Define cash flow and identify how to sustain a sufficient supply of it for the smooth running of your business.

  • Introduction - Case Study

  • ​Imagine Sandra owns a food truck that sells lunch meals. Every morning she drives to the same spot on the street in her city’s financial district. Thanks to the combination of her delicious servings, prime location, and hungry office workers on lunch break, Sarah’s food truck has steady business. Sometimes she even sells out her more popular foods. Business is great!

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • To make sure she’s consistently turning a profit, Sandra regularly checks her bank account at the end of every month to make sure that she has enough money to keep the business running for the next month. But is that all that is needed for her to make sure that her business stays successful? No. 

    Much more is required on her part to keep her business running, not just for the next month but for many years to come.

  • Case Study

  • ​Imagine Fumi & Family Furniture, an artisanal, family-run furniture shop that creates custom chairs, tables, and more. Fumiko also wants a better understanding of whether the family business is a financial success.

    What’s the best way for her to track whether her business is successful? The following discussion will help us decide.

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • How do you know whether your company is profitable or losing money? You can’t rely on your feelings or perceptions about how the company performs. Instead, you need to depend on facts – specifically, whether your business is making a profit or losing money.

    To determine which of​​ these it’s doing, you’ll want to create a profit and loss (P&L) statement. The profit and loss statement is a recap of your company’s income and expenses over a specified period of time. This period can be monthly, quarterly, or annually.

  • Case Study

  • Profit and Cash Flow

  • Profit and cash flow are essential aspects of a solid, thriving business. However, they are not the same thing. Profit is the money made selling your product or service minus expenses - what it costs to keep the business running.

    Cash flow, on the other hand, is all the cash moving in and out of your business. While profit is essential, cash flow is what will enable you to pay employees, pay for manufacturing, and pay for anything that allows you to maintain your business.

    Fundamentally, profit means that you've got money in the bank. Cash flow, however, means knowing when that money will become available for you to spend on present and future expenses.

    Cash flow can help you with the key points below:
    • Pay the rent for your business
    • Pay your employees
    • Pay for the manufacturing cost of your products
    • Pay to hire an external contractor

  • Keeping Track of Finances

  • Business owners have to juggle a lot of responsibilities, from sales to employee management to marketing. It can become a challenge to keep track of and closely monitor the business's finances, which in fact, should be a top priority. 

    You do not have to hold an Accounting degree to sort out the finances of your business by yourself. Dealing with numbers, recording and summarizing financial information can seem intimidating. However, there are ways to get around this important aspect of business management.

    If you form the habit of closely monitoring and organizing your finances, you will go a long way. Creating a list of all the accounting tasks that need to be checked and completed on a regular basis is a good place to start.

    Also, getting to know the significance of 3 basic financial reports will also help you evaluate the financial health of your business. These reports are the balance sheet, cash flow, and income statements.

  • Case Study

  • In 2016, over a thousand small business owners were asked to name the hardest parts of running a business. Money management issues topped the list. 

    Whether it’s growing revenue, increasing profits, or monitoring cash flow, managing money properly can be one of the biggest challenges to running a business. It makes sense because it’s also one of the most important.

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • Luckily you can learn what to do by learning what not to do. Let’s look at some mistakes in money management and how you can avoid them.

  • Luckily you can learn what to do by learning what not to do. Let’s look at some mistakes in money management and how you can avoid them.

  • Case Study

  • In 2016, over a thousand small business owners were asked to name the hardest parts of running a business. Money management issues topped the list. 

    Whether it’s growing revenue, increasing profits, or monitoring cash flow, managing money properly can be one of the biggest challenges to running a business. It makes sense because it’s also one of the most important.

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • Luckily you can learn what to do by learning what not to do. Let’s look at some mistakes in money management and how you can avoid them.

  • Case Study

  • In 2016, over a thousand small business owners were asked to name the hardest parts of running a business. Money management issues topped the list. 

    Whether it’s growing revenue, increasing profits, or monitoring cash flow, managing money properly can be one of the biggest challenges to running a business. It makes sense because it’s also one of the most important.

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • Luckily you can learn what to do by learning what not to do. Let’s look at some mistakes in money management and how you can avoid them.

  • Case Study

  • ​Let's say that a few years ago, a self-taught chef named Jimena used her own money to open a store selling her homemade cheese bread. Thanks to all the bread and cheese fans out there, Jimena's business has grown. 

    However, she's still using the same accounts and credit cards for her personal and business finances. Jimena figures that keeping everything together is the easiest way to go because she buys bread and cheese in bulk, some of which she uses for her store and some to snack on at home.

    What could go wrong? Let's consider two things:
    1. She will likely find it hard to stay organized and track which portion of cheese and bread went to making her store’s product and which went to make a midnight snack for herself.
    2. She will hardly be able to legally prove how much of her bread and cheese purchases were for legitimate business expenses versus personal use during the tax season.

  • Lesson Summary

  • In this course, you have learned that:
    • Setting a budget and tracking your expenses will help you stay on top of the health of your business and see what it'll take money-wise for your business to succeed. 
    • Organize your expenses into categories based on what taxes and deductibles your tax codes allow. This can help you down the line when you file your taxes.
    •  Take note of one-time, recurring, fixed, and variable expenses.
    • Don't rely on your feelings or perceptions about how the company is doing. Instead, you need to depend on facts – specifically, whether your business is making a profit or suffering losses. 
    • Create a profit and loss (P&L) statement. The profit and loss statement is a recap of your company's income and expenses over a specified period of time. This period can be monthly, quarterly, or annually.
    • Revenue is a company's income, often from selling goods or services. However, some companies also make revenue from other areas, such as rent collected from subleasing some of their space or selling used equipment.

  • Lesson Summary

  • In this course, you have learned that:
    • Setting a budget and tracking your expenses will help you stay on top of the health of your business and see what it'll take money-wise for your business to succeed. 
    • Organize your expenses into categories based on what taxes and deductibles your tax codes allow. This can help you down the line when you file your taxes.
    •  Take note of one-time, recurring, fixed, and variable expenses.
    • Don't rely on your feelings or perceptions about how the company is doing. Instead, you need to depend on facts – specifically, whether your business is making a profit or suffering losses. 
    • Create a profit and loss (P&L) statement. The profit and loss statement is a recap of your company's income and expenses over a specified period of time. This period can be monthly, quarterly, or annually.
    • Revenue is a company's income, often from selling goods or services. However, some companies also make revenue from other areas, such as rent collected from subleasing some of their space or selling used equipment.
